definition: **noun / slang.** Low-frequency vibration introduced when nearby doors slam, subs pound, or furniture resonates, "knocking-on" into a sensitive turntable setup. The term describes external mechanical energy transmitted through floors, walls, or shared surfaces that causes the stylus to track unwanted low-frequency motion, producing audible rumble or feedback. Common culprits include footsteps on wooden floors, washing machines, HVAC systems, and especially bass-heavy music from adjacent rooms or speakers. The phenomenon became particularly problematic with the rise of high-compliance cartridges in the 1970s and DJ culture in the 1980s, where sound system vibrations could easily couple into decks. Solutions range from simple isolation feet and wall-mounted shelves to sophisticated spring-suspension platforms and concrete plinths. Audiophiles obsess over knock-on mitigation, sometimes installing dedicated floating floors or placing turntables on separate structural supports. DJs developed techniques like the "finger brake" to dampen vibrations during live mixing. Modern direct-drive tables with heavy platters offer better resistance than lightweight belt-drives, though proper isolation remains essential for any serious listening environment where external vibrations threaten playback fidelity.
etymology: Coined in UK DJ and audiophile circles during the 1980s, combining "knock-on effect" (British English for cascading consequences) with acoustic "rumble" terminology.
